content: The "Child Support Enforcement Improvements Act of 1993" allows depository institutions to provide financial records to state child support enforcement agencies without liability. The "Child Support Enforcement Improvements Act of 1993" allows depository institutions to disclose financial records to state child support enforcement agencies without liability. State agencies can only use the financial records for establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations. Civil damages may apply for unauthorized disclosure by state officers or employees. If a State officer or employee discloses a financial record of an individual in violation, the individual can sue the State for damages. There is no liability if the disclosure was made in good faith but was erroneous. In such a case, the defendant may be liable to pay the plaintiff $1,000 for each unauthorized disclosure of a financial record. The term "depository institution" is defined as a financial institution covered by the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. The term "financial record" is defined by the Right to Financial Privacy Act of 1978. The term "State child support enforcement agency" refers to a state agency that administers child support programs. State child support enforcement agencies have access to and can use consumer reports in child support cases. State child support enforcement agencies can access consumer reports for establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations if paternity is established or acknowledged by the consumer, and the agency provides written notice to the consumer beforehand. State child support enforcement agencies can access consumer reports for establishing, modifying, or enforcing child support obligations if paternity is established or acknowledged by the consumer, and the agency certifies to the consumer reporting agency that the necessary requirements have been fulfilled. The term 'State child support enforcement agency' is defined as a State agency administering a program for child support obligations. SEC. 4. HEALTH CARE SUPPORT. The text chunk discusses the inclusion of health care coverage in child support orders, requiring orders to comply with state guidelines for health care costs of the child. It also mandates expedited consideration of any allegations related to this matter. The text chunk discusses the requirement for states to establish guidelines for health care coverage in child support orders, ensuring compliance with federal regulations. The Secretary must establish regulations with minimum standards for guidelines providing health care coverage for children in child support orders, including order contents, cost responsibility distribution, health insurance provisions, claims payment, and parental rights to insurance information. The Secretary must establish regulations with minimum standards for guidelines providing health care coverage for children in child support orders, including denial of coverage, penalties for non-compliance, and consideration of parents' circumstances. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is required to issue proposed regulations within 9 months and final regulations within 14 months to implement amendments related to the guidelines established in the preceding subsections. Additionally, dependent health insurance provided due to successful enforcement will be included in the Incentive Payments Program under Section 458(b) of the Social Security Act. The amendment to Section 458(b) of the Social Security Act states that successful enforcement of a support order requiring an absent parent to obtain health insurance for their children will be considered as support collection. The amount collected will be determined by the savings to the State from providing health insurance to the children. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will prescribe regulations within 6 months to implement the amendment. A study will be conducted to determine incentives for States to enforce noncustodial parents' obligations to pay for children's health and dental expenses. A report is due within 12 months of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will submit the results of a study on incentives for States to enforce noncustodial parents' obligations to pay for children's health and dental expenses to the Committees on Ways and Means and Finance. SEC. 5 amends the Social Security Act to include compliance standards for states regarding child support assistance. SEC. 6 requires employers to withhold wages for child support payments to the state within 10 days, with penalties for late payments. Amendment to the Social Security Act requires employers to make child support payments within 10 days, with a $1,000 penalty for late payments. Penalties collected must be used for the state plan approved under section 454. The amendments made by subsection (a) of this section will take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act. State plans approved under section 454 of the Social Security Act may delay compliance if state legislation is required to meet the new requirements. State plans under section 454 of the Social Security Act must meet additional requirements before the 1st day of the 1st calendar quarter after the State legislature's regular session following the enactment of this Act. If a State has a 2-year legislative session, each year is considered a separate regular session. SEC. 7. NATIONAL PARENT LOCATOR NETWORK. Section 453 of the Social Security Act is amended to expand the Parent Locator Service into a national network, allowing states to locate absent parents who owe child support or are subject to visitation orders by accessing records from other state agencies and federal sources. The Parent Locator Service is expanded into a national network under Section 453 of the Social Security Act. States can access records from other states and federal sources to locate absent parents for child support or visitation orders. This includes accessing files of other states, providing online and batch processing of locate requests, and directing requests to individual states or federal agencies. The Parent Locator Service is expanded into a national network under Section 453 of the Social Security Act. States can access records from other states and federal sources to locate absent parents for child support or visitation orders. The network aims to provide information within 48 hours and ensure easy access to courts through computer terminals.
